original_title: A Real-World Experience In PCB Dye-Sub Printing
original_content:
We all love PCB artwork, but those who create it work under the restriction of having a limited color palette to work with. If its not some combination of board, plating, solder mask, and silk screen, then it cant easily be rendered on a conventional PCB. Thats not the end of the story though, because its technically possible to print onto a PCB and have it any color you like. Is it difficult? Read [Spencer]s experience creating a rainbow Pride version of his RC2014 modular retrocomputer.
Dye-sublimation printing uses an ink that vaporizes at atmospheric pressure without a liquid phase, so a solid ink is heated and the vapor condenses back to solid on the surface to be printed. Commercial dye-sub printers are expensive, but theres a cheaper route in the form of an Epson printer that can be converted. This in turn prints onto a transfer paper, from which the ink is applied to the PCB in a T-shirt printing press.
[Spencer] took the advice of creating boards with all-white silkscreen applied, and has come up with a good process for creating the colored boards. There is still an issue with discoloration from extra heat during soldering, so he advises in the instructions for the kit to take extra care. It remains however a fascinating look at the process, and raises the important point that its now within the reach of perhaps a hackerspace.
Regular readers will know weve long held an interest in the manufacture of artistic PCBs.
title: PCBアートワークに色の制限がある？！
body: PCBアート作成者は、限られた色数しか使えないという制約の下で作業しています。しかし、染色昇華印刷を使用すると、どんな色でも印刷できます。手頃な価格のEpsonプリンターを改造する方法が紹介されています。サポートマスクが白色であることが重要です。ただし、はんだ付け時の余分な熱による変色の問題があります。
titles: PCBアートワークに色の制限がある？！
自分でパソコンを作って、その色も自分で選択

PCBアートの作り方、ついにhackerspaceでも可能
